Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Composition-independent thermometry technique for gaseous combustion

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511216 (Narayanaswamy)

A novel laser-based, accurate technique is proposed for measuring temperature in fuel burning devices, such as within an engine. The technique is of significance as precise knowledge of the temperature help design more energy-efficient devices with the potential to reduce pollutant emissions. The research will involve graduate students, while the outreach efforts will benefit K-12 education, especially in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) fields.

By adding a tracer amount of inert gas krypton to the combustion flow field, the PI proposes to develop a non-intrusive spectroscopic thermometry technique that has advantages over the other laser-based techniques developed so far. First and foremost, it does not require prior information about local chemical composition, as it is the dual fluorescence excitation of the argon species, rather than other reactive or intermediate species, that determines the local temperature. Second the proposed technique provides excellent temperature sensitivity across the combustion regime. Finally, it can be matured into a superior ground testing tool in large-scale facilities. A dual excitation fluorescence imaging leverages the Doppler and collisional broadening of the absorption spectrum to determine the temperature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  The project seeks to develop a laser-based thermometry technique for applications in flames at 1 atm. This project established the spectral scaling relations of absorption line broadening parameters of krypton gas in combustion environment. In addition to composition scaling, the temeprature scaling of krypton absorption broadening parameters in combustion environment was also established. These contributions are important because krypton is a non-polar species and the scaling relations avoid the complications from permanent dipole of species such as NO and CO that were previously studied. The scalings provided fundamental insights into the dispersive interactions when the absorbing and perturbing species have very similar energy level spacing.

Subsequently, the project demonstrated two composition independent thermometry techniques. The first technique is a excitation scan approach that provided mean temperature field with arbitrary local composition. The second technique is a two-line approach, which provide instantaneous 2D temperature fields. This technique was demonstrated in both non-sooting and sooting flames. Six journal articles  and 4 peer reviewed conference articles are published from this work. Two Ph.D. students (one partially) is funded through this grant.

Broader Impact: Four UG students, two from minority community, were engaged in the research effort and were mentored by the Ph.D. student. One of the UG researcher from minority community was a co-author in one of the journal article [36] and a speaker in AIAA Student Conference 2016. The PI also organized many 30 min long “Color the Fire” workshops as a part of summer camp. The participants were exposed to the idea of emission spectrum and the association of emitted colors with electronic transition.
